questions.question: 2. Which extra data structure is used in radix sort?

explanations.a: Incorrect. Heaps are used in heap sort, not radix sort.
explanations.b: Correct. Radix sort uses auxiliary arrays (buckets) to temporarily hold elements grouped by digit values during each pass of the algorithm.
explanations.c: Incorrect. While queues could theoretically be used, the standard implementation uses arrays.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Radix sort requires extra data structures, specifically arrays.

questions.question: 3. Radix Sort has worse space complexity than Bubble Sort

explanations.a: Correct. Radix sort has O(N+K) space complexity due to auxiliary arrays, while bubble sort has O(1) space complexity as it's an in-place algorithm.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Radix sort does have worse space complexity than bubble sort.

questions.question: 4. Radix sort is a generalization of which sorting algorithm

explanations.a: Incorrect. Radix sort is not related to bubble sort's comparison-based approach.
explanations.b: Correct. Radix sort is a generalization of counting sort, applying counting sort to each digit position from least to most significant.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Selection sort is a comparison-based algorithm unrelated to radix sort.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Merge sort uses a divide-and-conquer approach different from radix sort.

questions.question: 5. Radix sort can perform better than comparison based sorting

explanations.a: Correct. Radix sort can achieve O(d*N) time complexity where d is the number of digits, which can be faster than comparison-based sorts' O(N log N) lower bound for certain inputs.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Radix sort can indeed perform better than comparison-based sorting algorithms in specific scenarios.
